captions.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

CHRIS HARRIS: Clever people
keep telling me that

everything will be
electric soon.

This fills me with the fear of
God, because I don't much like
electric cars.

But there's now a race among
some makers to prove that
electric can be exciting.

And the first to land is the
Mercedes SLS Electric Drive.

But is it a genuine alternative
to a supercar?

The SLS Electric Drive is a
strange mix of the familiar
and unfamiliar.

I know it's a bit odd to say I'm
familiar with the interior

of the SLS, but I did
run one for a while.

And it's quite conventional
Mercedes in its layout.

But of course, being electric,
it just has a couple of

slightly strange things that
look profoundly different to
the normal production car.

To start with, we have this rev
counter here that shows

percentage of energy
being used.

It has a battery temperature
gauge, and it has a battery
life gauge.

The center screen is a computer
readout that tells

me, again, how much battery life
I've got, because that

seems to be the pertinent
thing.

The central screen here, well
they've taken the and now

turned it into something that
looks like a computer game.
It's absolutely fantastic.
You'll see that now.

It tells you what's going on
and where torque is going.

The rest of the controls
are quite conventional.
Got a normal steering wheel.

My paddles, they now control
the amount of brake
regeneration I've got.

So I can either have a lot of
brake regeneration, which

gives massive retardation when
you let off the pedal, and a

lot of regenerative power going
back into the batteries.

But it does mean that if there
was a car following me on the

road, they'd probably
rear end me.

Gear lever is the same
as the normal SLS.

You pull it back into drive,
there's a bit of a whirring as

the handbrake goes off, and
now in complete silence.

And honestly, at the moment, the
loudest thing is the fan
that's on two at the moment.
We just roll away.

And we do so in one of the three
driving modes, this one
called comfort.
Comfort is as described.

It gives us the easiest,
most relaxed throttle
position in the car.

So we've got quite a long
throttle as we push on now,
doing 25, 30 miles an hour.
Just remarkable.

Less spring rate than I think
in a standard SLS.

The car's heavy, obviously,
nearly 2.2 tons, with a bit
more with two people on board.

I've got nice steering weight,
not too light.
Circuit's very slippery today.
Performance--

well, at the moment I've got
around 440 kilowatts.

I probably better do the math
on that for you in a minute.

But it does mean that if I thump
my foot down, it doesn't

feel as quick as
a standard SLS.
It doesn't.
But even so, this is--

in this form, in its most
sanitized form-- the SLS

Electric Drive still feels like
a proper performance car.

It's still got good amounts
of performance.
Look at that.
Foot down, 60, 70, 80--
that's quite quick.
Ceramic brakes work well.

The torque vectoring that's
going on here is massively
complicated.
It's unbelievable.

We've got four electric motors,
one at each corner,

and all of the torque would be
monitored the whole time

according to your steering
angle, lord knows what else.

As a calibration exercise,
this is unprecedented.
So let's go into sport mode.

So now I've got a slightly
more responsive throttle.

And I've got a chassis which is
trying to make things a bit
sharper for me.
The car feels--

yeah, certainly feels a
bit more responsive.
This is just freakish.

This whole torque vectoring
thing is freakish.

I think torque vectoring might
almost be more interesting

than the fact that this car
is electrically driven.

It's the new snake oil of
chassis design, isn't it?

I mean, it almost gives
infinitesimal possibilities,

the fact that you
can put negative
torque into one wheel.

So the wheel that's moving the
slowest in the corner, if you

want, you can drag that
wheel back to nothing.
That's incredible.

You can make the
car just turn.

And this car does feel very
agile for something so heavy.

In comfort and sport, the car
is limited to 200 kilometers

per hour, so 125 miles
an hour in old money.

That's about fast enough,
isn't it?

And if you drive the car like
this, ie not too harshly, you
could probably cover about--
I don't know, 160, 170 miles.
If you gun it, well, yeah.

It becomes a bit more
inefficient then.

Interestingly, I tried to push
Mercedes on some real CO2

figures, because
they claim that
the car is zero emissions.
Well it's not, is it?

It pushes the emissions
to another point
in the carbon cycle.

If a normal SLS is 300 and
something grams per kilometer,
then this--

realistically in a northern
European nation that uses a

mixture of nuclear, coal, and
increasingly, some renewable
energy sources--

this is around 15 to 20
grams per kilometer.

So it's still pretty
efficient.
Wow.

This is quite alarmingly quick,
even in sport mode.
Now, sport plus.
Sport plus.

I've got a much more responsive
throttle now.

And I now have 740 something
horsepower, 1,000 newton

meters of torque,
737 foot pounds.

And I'm limited to 150
miles an hour.
That won't be a problem here.

But this is a slippery track,
so I've got to be
a little bit careful.
What happens?

Well, the torque vectoring is
doing an incredible job of
keeping me on the circuit.
It's very slippery today.

And what it's doing is allowing
each wheel to do its

maximum given the
circumstances.

But rather than getting really
juddery brakes, it actually

feels like the tire has reached
its limits of grip and
just stops there.

Just keep your foot planted, and
it's seamless and smooth.

And then when it lets go in a
straight line, I mean, it's
quick, isn't it?

Neil's speechless next
to me, recording.
This is new.
This is profoundly new.
It's genuinely fast, guys.
It's genuinely fast.

I'm not sure what this means
for the future of the

motorcar, because this is
400,000 pounds by the time
you've paid a few taxes.

There's no right-hand
drive version.

And it's a technology that's
available now, but it's also
massively complex.

It's not ultimately as usable
or as flexible as
a combustion engine.

And it's not a car for
the people, is it?
Although this is modular.

So imagine 740 something
horsepower.

Well, you could take a third
of this and stick it in an
A-class, and you're away.

Not as much fun as
that though.

I mean, that is just back to the
future when you squirt it
down the straight, isn't it?
Blimey O'Reilly.
Torque vectoring--
very, very interesting.

Now, there are three
modes here, and we
can play with them.

So we have the ability to switch
off torque dynamics
into sport now.

So this allows me, again, to
have a completely different
chassis setup on the car.
So this is less cautious.
It will allow a bit of slip.
Look at that, a bit of slip.

Now, this is all done
through electronics.

It's slippery as hell, and
it's just managing
everything for me.

And it's all done on
steering angle.

What's really freakish about the
dynamics of this car with

the torque vectoring is that in
a conventional sports car,

you have the same ultimate
behavior of the car, and you

just play with the levels
of intervention.

Yeah, you can put more support
into the car by stiffening the
dampening up.

And you can play with other bits
and bobs, and some cars

have differentials that will
change a bit as well.

But ultimately, the character
of the car is the same.

You just play with the
intervention levels.

With this car, when you go from
comfort to sport plus,

you have a totally
different car.
It feels quite different.
It performs differently.

The axles behave differently
according to the grip levels

and the amount of power
being thrown at them.
Bizarre.

So sport mode gives us
a bit more slip.
Mega.
Absolutely mega.

The vaguely oversteering
electric car.
Tell you what, though.

We could try the completely
oversteering electric car.
[CAR SKIDS]
[INTERMITTENT BUZZING]

CHRIS HARRIS: That's an electric
car in a skid.
[LOUD BUZZING]

CHRIS HARRIS: About five minutes
ago, I was out of the

track, which is wet,
oversteering a four wheel
drive electric car.
I've never done that before.

So rather than stand around that
car and try and have my

mind blown, we've come inside
to this cutaway.

And I want some of this
technology explained to me--

how this works, why it works,
and how they've reached this

level of performance from the
car, because I just wasn't
expecting it.
OK.

First of all, four electric
motors, yeah?

JAN FEUSTEL: Four electric
motors, one in each wheel.

CHRIS HARRIS: Torque split,
25% per corner?

JAN FEUSTEL: That's the
basic setup, yes.

CHRIS HARRIS: But
it can change?

JAN FEUSTEL: And it will change
if you're driving in a
dynamic way.

Torque vectoring will help you
set the right torque on the

right wheel in the
right second.

CHRIS HARRIS: So we have the
battery packs mainly in the

center of the vehicle within the
carbon structure, which is

completely different
to an SLS.

So even though the car looks
like an SLS on the outside,

underneath, it's nothing to do
with an SLS at all, is it?
It's completely different.

JAN FEUSTEL: It's completely
different.

We changed the body in white in
terms of the center of the

vehicle, the spine
of the vehicle.

We do have a zero intrusion cell
made out of carbon fiber,

which is pretty much the
backbone of the vehicle, gives

the body in white a lot
of the stiffness
that you already felt.
And it's additional--

it's an intelligent way of our
strategy of lightweight

performance, since that battery
housing is part of the
body in white.
CHRIS HARRIS: OK.

Actually in twist, is this
stiffer than a normal SLS?

JAN FEUSTEL: Yes it is, due to
the carbon fiber housing.

CHRIS HARRIS: That's
interesting.

But we have a lot of
mass down here.

We have 550 kilograms or so,
don't we, of batteries?
JAN FEUSTEL: Yes.

CHRIS HARRIS: But the actual
center of gravity is quite

good, because it's low and in
the middle of the car, yes?
JAN FEUSTEL: Yes.

And the center of gravity in
total, in the center of

gravity of the vehicle, is about
an inch lower than in
the regular SLS.

CHRIS HARRIS: The electric
motors-- how much power do we

have coming from the front and
the rear axle in terms of
electric motor power?
What's the split?

JAN FEUSTEL: Each electric motor
provides 138 kilowatts,
so they all four are the same.
Basic setup is 25% each.

So the total is 552 kilowatts,
which is 750 horsepower.
And the--
CHRIS HARRIS: Sorry.

How do you say that
without smiling?

You've made an electric
car 750 horsepower.
JAN FEUSTEL: 750--

CHRIS HARRIS: That is
utterly bat [BLEEP]
isn't it?

Think about it, 750 horsepower
and 1,000
newton meters of torque.
Carry on.
Sorry.

Just try not to smile when
you say it, all right?

JAN FEUSTEL: With 750
horsepower, it's the most
powerful electrical car.

And it's the most powerful
AMG ever.

CHRIS HARRIS: Let's have a
little look around a couple of
bits and bobs.
Talk me through the cells.

The cells come from
South Korea?
JAN FEUSTEL: Yes.
CHRIS HARRIS: How many cells?
JAN FEUSTEL: 864.

CHRIS HARRIS: OK, in all, and
they come in blocks of--
is it three big blocks?

JAN FEUSTEL: Actually,
what we see here is
what we call one module.

And we do have 12 equal modules
in the vehicle.

Four of these modules are
mounted together to a battery.

So from an electric point of
view, we do have three equal
batteries in the car.

CHRIS HARRIS: And I suppose
from an R&D perspective--

because this is an R&D project,
and we have to
remember that--

it's entirely possible
to take one of those.

You could take one of those
and put them in a car.
JAN FEUSTEL: You can.

You won't have that much
fun, but you can.

CHRIS HARRIS: But you still
have a third of 750
horsepower, don't you?
JAN FEUSTEL: Yes.

CHRIS HARRIS: That's
quite a lot--

JAN FEUSTEL: Yeah, that's
quite good.

CHRIS HARRIS: --by conventional
standards.
How long do these last for?

If you recycle them properly,
if you charge them and

discharge them properly, how
long does that last for?

JAN FEUSTEL: During development,
we did a lot of

testing in terms of cycling,
of aging, corrosion tests.

And we kind of torture our
components to make sure they
will last in customers' hands.

But that battery is made
to last for 10 years.
CHRIS HARRIS: 10 years.

So we're not worried
about that.
In terms of range--

so if I drive the car normally,
I don't try and

drive too fast, I keep the car
in comfort mode, maybe for 20%

of the time of a full charge, I
have it in sport plus and I
go a bit quicker.

How many kilometers
do you think?

JAN FEUSTEL: The certified
range is 250 kilometers.

But as you said, the real life
range that you can achieve in

an everyday use might
be around 200.

This is what we expect, even
though if you know how to

drive the vehicle in an economic
way, you will be able
to reach 250.

But if you're cruising in, let's
say, more or less normal

traffic, 200 is a realistic
answer.

CHRIS HARRIS: 225 miles, which
is still a long way, given

that I'm not used to electric
cars having any range
whatsoever.

Just talk me through the
way that each gear box
works on each axle.
Can we have a look at that?
JAN FEUSTEL: Sure.

CHRIS HARRIS: I presume-- and
you'll tell me I'm wrong now.
And we're on video.
He's recording--

do we just have a reduction
gear effectively here?
Is that what we're doing?

We're just taking a motor and
reducing its speed down?

JAN FEUSTEL: Basically,
that's what we do.

We have one, two electric motors
are facing each other.

They're mounted onto
one gear box.

And inside this gear box,
actually, there's two

independent gear
sets in there.

So the right motor doesn't know
what the left one does.
They're facing to each other.
There's two sets of gears.

And there's a driveshaft
connected to the axles.

So differential is realized
in an electronic way.

And that's why torque vectoring
can tell that motor

independently from this
one what we want
to do with the vehicle.

And that is the key for the fast
reaction and the ability

to control the vehicle
in a dynamic way.

CHRIS HARRIS: Talk me through,
effectively, negative torque,

the way that you can apply what
you call negative torque
to a wheel in a situation.
How does that work?

JAN FEUSTEL: Negative torque
is a thing that you--

you might have difficulties to
understand what negative
torque means.

For instance, if you go through
a corner on your

right, these two wheels on the
left hand side, they get all

the vehicle load, so you can
put the maximum positive
torque onto these two wheels.

If you're turning into the
corner, the two left wheels,
they get this negative torque.

And it's not that we're turning
wheels backwards.

It's more like breaking down the
wheel, or kind of try to
turn it backwards.

If you rip it off and turn
it backwards, then
you lose the grip.
That's not what you want.

So you kind of break it down
and turn it backwards.

And by moving this way, these
two have maximum torque

positive and these
two negative.
This is--

you can imagine, it turns
automatically
without steering angle.

CHRIS HARRIS: You're
not actually
running the motor backwards.

You're just pulling the
torque back to zero.
JAN FEUSTEL: Exactly, yes.

CHRIS HARRIS: And that's what
you call negative torque?

JAN FEUSTEL: Well, we don't
turn it back to zero.

We are even able to
turn it backwards.

CHRIS HARRIS: So it's actually
decelerating the wheel?
JAN FEUSTEL: Yes.

CHRIS HARRIS: And this is all
done through the gear box and

the motor, nothing to
do with the brake?

You're not using the brake
disc at all to trim it?

JAN FEUSTEL: Torque vectoring
doesn't work with brakes,

since brakes kind of-- it takes
some time to activate

them and to get the
pressure there.

The electric motors, they set
it right as you want it.
CHRIS HARRIS: Madness.
Absolute madness.

OK, I think that's about
all the tech we can
digest in that period.

But that is a car that requires
a lot of thinking

once you've driven it, and I
need to go and think now about
what I've experienced.

I don't think it's an immediate
solution for the

super sports car, because
obviously it's expensive, and

it doesn't quite have the range,
and it's heavy, and it
has some downsides.

But if you told me two or three
years ago that there

would be an SLS for sale that
was completely electric that

could perform like this,
I just wouldn't
have believed you.

The SLS Electric Drive is too
limited and too heavy to be a

genuine replacement
to a supercar.

But it's much, much
more exciting
than I'd ever expected.

This is a showcase for
what's coming.

And it's mostly good news,
even if it looks like the

smaller, lighter batteries we
really need are still at least
a decade away.
It's a totally bizarre car.

I feel like Marty McFly
the moment he got
into the bloody DeLorean.

If you made a time machine
out of an SLS--
it's absolutely bizarre.

title: Mercedes SLS Electric Drive. Can Volts Ever Match Pistons? - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS

Nice review, a couple of questions:

1) Why doesn't it (or in general electric cars) have gears? Are gears just 
pointless on electric cars?

2) Is there no way of getting it to charge in a few minutes rather than 20 
hours? Currently it only takes 1/2 mins to refuel your car, so taking 20 
hours is a huge step backward. Surely there has got to be a way to charge 
quicker?﻿

comments.text:
Adding to lucas knorr, one of the challenges of charging an EV (electric 
vehicle) battery, is the charging setup needed. There's thousands of 
kilowatts in an EV battery, and if you were to want to charge it within 
minutes, you would have force more power through the charging device than 
would be safe. Generally speaking, the charging wires are simply not big 
enough to transfer that kind of power. They would explode if you tried. 
Currently, the size of cable you would need to charge an EV within minutes 
would be too heavy to even lift, and not only that, but you'd have to have 
that cable attached directly to your nearest power plant.
comments.author: Jonah Janko

comments.text:
Electric motors don't need gears, and having them wouldn't do them any 
favors. Electric motors have the same amount of torque at 0 rpm as they do 
at their max rpm. They usually have a set gear ratio because they can only 
spin so fast, but that's what sets the top speed of the car. The charge 
length depends on the current battery technology, and will improve over 
time (with newer models once the technology is available). Different cars 
take different amounts of time to charge depending on how much power they 
store and what battery technology they use. You can charge a Tesla half 
full during the amount of time it takes you to eat lunch. Unlike a regular 
car which you fill up when empty, you charge your car when at home just 
like you would your iPhone. You would only need to worry about charge time 
while on a road trip, but as long as you take pit stops for meals or 
bathroom breaks you will be fine. Tesla is also working on a way to swap 
out your low battery pack for a fully charged one in less time than it 
would take to fill a tank of gas. I am no expert on this subject, but 
hopefully this answers your question.

comments.text:

secret that we mess up sometimes ... now if you are stitting at home or the 
office and your System crashes ... that's okay .. restart and you ae good

If you are going 280 Km/h on the highway (in germany that's just fine in

comments.text:
Aircraft have only become safer as electronics has taken over. It's really 
just a matter of standards and adhering to them. The general IT industry 
*is* pretty lackadaisical about quality control, but that doesn't mean it 
can't be done. The aerospace, aeronautics, industrial manufacturing, and 
military industries all do quality control incredibly well. It's very rare 
for bugs to crop up that are dangerous or show-stoppers in any of these 
industries, and they're all 100% electronic/software-driven these days.

It may be that we'll see the introduction of professional accreditation to 
the software design industry as these things become more widespread-- 
similar to what we have with doctors, lawyers, plumbers, electricians, and 
so forth. That's probably coming within the next 10 years or so-- and it 
probably should. There's no reason we should still be living today at the 
garage/basement weekend tinkerer level of software design in the 
professional/industrial level of the software industry. It's no big deal if 
mom-and-pop.com goes down or has a database connection issue now and then, 
but when you're doing things that matter, it needs to be approached from an 
entirely different perspective. The industry is really far behind on that 
today.

comments.author: K Sadek

comments.text:
I see where you're not understanding what's happening. That's exactly what 
regenerative braking is-- applying a reverse force (torque) to the motor. 
It just doesn't apply so much reverse torque that the tire loses traction 
and the motor actually *turns* backward. It's basically the same thing as 
stepping on the gas pedal to accelerate vs. stepping on the gas pedal even 
more to spin the tires, except it does this backwards, and the reverse 
torque applied against the forward rotation induces an electric current 
that feeds back into the battery, which is what regenerative braking is.

The clever thing about this kind of electric torque vectoring is that 
instead of putting that regenerative braking current into the battery, if 
it's wired and programmed right, it can actually just send that current 
straight over to the other wheels which will add extra power without having 
to take it out of the battery.

comments.text:
Back in the '70s, the Aston Martin Lagonda featured the most ambitious, 
complicated and in-manageable dashboard ever placed on a car. More than 
what was expected to be spent in the whole card development had finished 
into that CRT monstrosity and, to date, you need a wizard - more than a 
cars electric system specialist - to fix anything that goes awry.

Fast forward forty years, a good engineer could replace the whole unholy 
mess with a couple of 7" LCD driven by a Rapsberry, or an Arduino, and a 
A/D acquisition board, given a month or so - well, I know people who could 
do it in the week-ends, just for fun.

Which is, really, the reason why today we see LCD screens as main 
instruments in some low volume sports car - they cost a bit more in pieces 
and bits, and do not appeal much to the more conservative buyers, but are 
really a lot  simpler to engineer. You just have to place a fancy graphic 
on the LabView programs are usually used for testing.

I think that, for this car, it is pretty much the same.

Overly complicated, difficult to maintain etc. with today's technology.

MB built it, probably, more to have a test-bed for its torque vectoring and 
other technologies, that we are probably going to see in the future, 
probably in hybrid cars.

As such it is a beautifully looking, horribly costly toy that they will 
sell to someone more interested in showing off than drive it daily.

With the caveat that, being so costly (400k pounds?), this machines will 
receive proper maintenance, probably directly from technicians out of MB 
technical services, and these will report the problems encountered to the 
designers of the original system, to fix the quirks that escaped the 
in-house testing -  and there are always some.

So, in the end, these are experimental test-beds, sold at a premium.

I, for one, am happy that some sheik is going to spend a lot money to test 
the tech that's going to be in my son clunky, used, first car, in 
twenty-five - thirty years (the guy still has to born, and I am single).
*___________*

It's not like it's the first time, either.

The 300 SL of the 1954 had a mechanical injection system that mandated Oil 
change every 1500 km, and made it pretty fragile if the owner had the habit 
of making just short trips (it poured gasoline, after shut-down, till the 
engine moved; if the engine was cold, gasoline could not evaporate and 
tended to build up, diluting the oil).

20 years after, the grandsons of the same system helped making MB gasoline 
engines one of the most reliable on the market, from the '70s throughout 
the  early '90s.
 ﻿

comments.author: Kutub Uddin

comments.text:
I have a so called smart phone, but I still only use it for one thing, and 
that is dialing a call and answering a call, with some texting here and 
there. Personally i could still go with a home phone and leave the cell 
phone to road side emergencies. And I know a lot of people like this. It's 
a luxury rather than a necessity. It is also built around marketing 
gimmicks. It was born by the gimmick and will die if it doesn't have a new 
gimmick. 
But let's talk about cars. People expect a certain something in their cars, 
whether that be reliability, economy, luxury, or performance. There are 
usually two ends to the spectrum with a lot of balances in between. Each 
car tries to have a little or a lot of what people want from the list 
above, and it's broken down into sectors of price. It always comes back to 
what people can afford. Usually these products always start out as 
exclusive luxuries that only a hand full of people can buy. It creates a 
market that eventually expands enough and trickles down to the rest of the 
people. Initial money made gets spent making things better. Longer battery 
life, more places to fill up those batteries and quicker fill times. And 
the price goes down. 
The thought of being completely free of gasoline is definitely a 
revolution. And not only that, but even the average person can for the 
first time, see the wheels of business motion taking shape and perhaps they 
too can get in on the early stages of the market. 
I don't discard companies like Nokia, or say they are "left behind", as if 
every company always makes the best or right decision all the time. They 
could be working on something even bigger and make a come back too. 
McDonalds is the largest fast food chain in the world, but that doesn't 
mean they're the best, or that they'll be around forever. Same with 
Wal-Mart. 
If you ask me, I'd rather have something that just works for the next ten 
years without any hassle. Make something so good that people don't want to 
trade it in a week later for the next new thing. Make something memorable. 
Something that matters. To me that's real progress. And good business.

comments.text:
Beautiful car.  Loved the driving impressions.  Geeked out over the 
technicals.

Surprised that at around half a million bucks, it barely has more battery 
storage at 66 kWh than the *Tesla Model S 60*, which has a list price of 
$69,900.  Why did *Mercedes-Benz AMG* go with a South Korean supplier, when 
they already have a relationship with *Tesla Motors*?  They could have used 
lighter battery cells, with higher power density, lowered the weight, and 
increased the range significantly.

This is about as perplexing as the fact the *BMW **i8* has one-third the 
battery capacity of the *BMW **i3*, which costs one-third as much.  Except 
that if the *i8* had a 66 kWh capacity instead of only 7.1 kWh, it wouldn't 
need the 3-cylinder turbocharged engine at all.  It could have been fully 
electric instead of hybrid and ran circles around the *Mercedes-Benz SLS 
AMG Electric Drive*, for over $300,000 less money.

Perhaps auto manufacturers keep buying their batteries from *LexCorp*?﻿

comments.text:
+hold the chicken 
1. Hydrogen is not cleaner than battery by a long shot. Just making 
hydrogen and using it in a car is at least two times dirtier (depending on 
technology), because it takes at least two times the amount of electricity 
to get hydrogen to the user than to use that electricity to charge your car.

2. When talking about emisions everybody compares the tail-pipe eision of 
an ICE car to emmisions of a coal power plant, nobody takes in acount the 
emisions that are generated before you even burn  the gasoline in a car. 
And the world average amont of electricity  that comes from coal is about 
50%.

I actually did the calculations on CO2 emmisions, and came to the conlution 
that the electric car emits more CO2 than gasoline if more than 77% of the 
energy that goes into charging the car comes from the least efficient coal 
plant.
In addition to that, refining oil uses electricity (not longer oil it self, 
because it is cheaper), and for geting 1 liter of gasoline out of oil you 
need to put in the amont of electrical energy that could propel electric 
car the same distance than 0,5l of that gasoline.

So if you switch to electric and you charge your car 100% from coal plants 
you still produce 60% less CO2 than gasoline car (all together not just 
tail-pipe).

Furthare more the "dirtines" of a car is not mesaured in just CO2 but allso 
in NOx and SOx, which couse acid rain and contribute to resperatory 
deseases.
Large power-plants have allot of filters that prevent those emitions going 
into the air, in contrast to ICE cars that only have a catalitic converter, 
which is not as afficient as those filters, and is completley useles on the 
first 5min of driving, because they have not yet wormed up to their 
operating temperature.
